subsc: Central government administration,Sub-national government administration,Other social services,Agricultural extension and research,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the Natural Resources
            Management Project's outcome is considered to be
            satisfactory, despite some short-comings in building
            institutional capacity. Lessons drawn from project
            implementation include: 1) Participatory management of
            state-owned forests resources is technically, socially, and
            economically feasible. 2) When encroachment by
            agriculturists has gone beyond a certain level (50 to 60
            percent), the project's approach to formulation of
            collaborative management plans is not viable. 3) Management
            plans that only rely upon promotion of sustainable
            forest-based income generating activities do not take into
            account the full extent of the existing sources of
            livelihood of local people. Future management plans need to
            take a more holistic view of people's sources of income
            and not just from the perspective of the resource being
            managed. 4) Government commitment is variable on two fronts:
            a) planning and budgeting, and b) commitment to
            institutional reform. 5) There are important trade-offs
            between building government capacity to monitor impact and
            the need for projects to obtain objective data on impact in
            order to learn lessons and justify investments. 6) There are
            many tested technologies for natural resource management
            that are available "off the shelf." Therefore,
            research should not be supply driven but rather demand driven.
